5: P-Charge-Info: A Private Header Field (P-Header) Extension to the
8: This text documents the current usage of P-Charge-Info, an existing
9: Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) private header field (P-Header)
10: used to convey billing information about the party to be charged.
11: This P-Header is currently used in production by several equipment
12: vendors and carriers and has been in use since at least 2007.  This
13: document details the registration of this header field with IANA.

74: In certain network configurations, several network entities have
75: found it useful to decouple the identity of the caller (what is
76: normally thought of as "Caller ID") from the identity/number used for
77: billing purposes.  This document records the current usage of
78: P-Charge-Info, a private SIP header field, to provide simple billing
79: information and details the registration of this header field with
80: IANA as required by Section 4 of [RFC5727].
81: In a typical configuration, the identity of the caller, commonly
82: referred to as "Caller ID" by end users, is derived from one of the
85: o  From (in the absence of P-Asserted-Identity)
86: (NOTE: Some service providers have also used the Remote-Party-ID
87: header field, but this was never standardized and was replaced by
89: This identity/number is typically presented to the receiving user
90: agent (UA), where it is usually displayed for the end user.  It is
91: also typically used for billing purposes by the network entities
93: However, in some network configurations, the "Caller ID" presented to
94: the receiving UA may be different from the number to be used for
96: In this case, there exists a need for a way to pass an additional
97: billing identifier that can be used between network entities in order
99: Several carriers, application providers, and equipment providers have
100: been using the P-Charge-Info header field since at least 2007 as a
101: simple mechanism to exchange this billing identifier.
102: This document specifies the use of the P-Charge-Info header field in
103: INVITE requests.  The header field might be useful in other SIP
104: messages, but such use is beyond the scope of this document.
111: "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in

114: The key words describe requirements needed to interoperate with
117: This document has been prepared to document the existing deployed
118: usage of the P-Charge-Info header field and to comply with Section 4
119: of [RFC5727] in registering this header field with IANA.  It is noted
120: that RFC 5727 specifically deprecates new usage of "P-" header
121: fields, but P-Charge-Info has been in deployment since before 2007
122: and predates RFC 5727.  Given this, the authors believe that
123: P-Charge-Info is a "grandfathered case" per Section 4 of RFC 5727.
125: The simplest use case for P-Charge-Info is an enterprise environment
126: where each SIP endpoint has a direct number that is passed by the
127: enterprise SIP proxy across to a SIP proxy at a SIP service provider
128: who provides connectivity to the Public Switched Telephone Network
129: (PSTN).  Rather than cause the SIP service provider to have to track
130: each individual direct number for billing purposes, the enterprise
131: SIP proxy sends, in the P-Charge-Info header field, a single billing
132: identifier that the SIP service provider uses for billing purposes.
133: As another example, a hosted telephony provider or hosted voice-
134: application provider may have a large SIP network with customers who
135: are distributed over a very large geographic area and use local-
136: market PSTN numbers, although the network has only a very few actual
138: The customers may all have local phone numbers, yet outgoing calls
139: are actually routed across a SIP network and out specific PSTN
140: gateways or across specific SIP connections to other SIP service
141: providers.  The hosted provider may want to pass a billing identifier
142: to its SIP service providers either for the purpose of simplicity in
143: billing or to obtain better rates from the SIP service providers.
148: 5.1.  Applicability Statement for the P-Charge-Info Header Field
149: The P-Charge-Info header field is applicable within a single private
150: administrative domain or between different administrative domains
151: where there is a trust relationship between the domains.
152: 5.2.  Usage of the P-Charge-Info Header Field
153: The P-Charge-Info header field is used to convey information about
154: the identity of the party to be charged.  The P-Charge-Info header
155: field is typically inserted into a SIP request, usually an INVITE, by
157: o  the SIP proxy on the originating network;
158: o  a PSTN gateway acting as a SIP UA; or
159: o  an application server generating billing information.
160: P-Charge-Info is to be used by the SIP entity that provides billing
161: services for a session.  This could be an entity that is generating
162: billing records or another entity interacting with it.  Upon receipt
163: of an INVITE request with the P-Charge-Info header field, such an
164: entity MAY use the value present in P-Charge-Info as indicating the
165: party responsible for the charges associated with the session.  This
166: decision, for example, could be based on local policy.
168: The P-Charge-Info header field may be inserted by PSTN gateways or
169: application servers acting as a SIP UA.
170: The P-Charge-Info header field is ignored by an end-user UA and
171: should not normally be received by such a UA.  It MUST NOT be sent to
172: an end-user UA, as this would provide information to the UA about the
173: party to be charged; providing such information may cause security-
174: related issues; for example, calling-party information would be known
175: by the UA for an otherwise anonymous call.  A UA SHOULD ignore it if
176: it receives this header.  Similarly, an end-user UA originating a SIP
177: message SHOULD NOT insert this header field.
178: A PSTN gateway or application server acting as a UA MAY use the
179: content of the P-Charge-Info header field present in an INVITE
180: request it received as the identity to be charged for the session for
181: billing-related procedures, e.g., in a billing record or during
182: interaction with another entity generating billing records.  A PSTN
186: gateway or application server acting as a UA MAY use the content of
187: the P-Charge-Info header field to populate information about the
188: identity of the party to charge in another type of signaling, such as
191: A SIP proxy that supports this extension and receives a request,
192: typically a SIP INVITE, MAY insert a P-Charge-Info header field.  The
193: contents of the inserted header field may be decided based on local
194: policy or by querying an external entity to determine the identity of
196: When a proxy receives an INVITE request, it MAY use the content of
197: the P-Charge-Info header field contained in the request for billing-
198: related procedures, e.g., in a billing record or during interaction
199: with another entity that is generating billing records.
200: A SIP proxy that does not support this extension will pass any
201: received P-Charge-Info header field unmodified, in compliance with
203: A proxy supporting this extension MUST remove the P-Charge-Info
204: header field before sending a request to a UA that is not acting as a
205: PSTN gateway or appropriate application server, if the role of the UA
208: The content of the P-Charge-Info header field is typically just a
209: SIP/tel URI used as a billing indicator.  An example could be as
215: Any other applicable SIP URI could be used.
220: This RFC contains the definition of one or more SIP header fields
221: that allow choosing between addr-spec and name-addr when constructing
222: header-field values.  [RFC8217] prohibits the use of addr-spec if its
223: value would contain a comma, semicolon, or question mark.
224: The private header field specified here is described in both prose
225: and an augmented Backus-Naur Form (BNF) defined in [RFC5234].
226: Further, several BNF definitions are inherited from SIP and are not
227: repeated here.  Implementors need to be familiar with the notation
228: and contents of [RFC3261] and [RFC5234] to understand this document.
229: The syntax of the P-Charge-Info header field is described as follows:
231: ; name-addr and addr-spec are specified in RFC 3261
232: The SIP URI contained in the name-addr/addr-spec is the billing
233: indicator that is passed between the parties.
235: This specification registers a new proprietary SIP header field
236: according to the procedures defined in [RFC5727].
238: The P-Charge-Info private header field has been registered in the
239: "Header Fields" subregistry of the "Session Initiation Protocol (SIP)
246: Given that the information contained in the P-Charge-Info header
247: field will be used for billing purposes, the proxies and other SIP
248: entities that share this information MUST have a trust relationship.
252: If an untrusted entity were inserted between the trusted entities, it
253: could potentially interfere with the billing records for the call.
254: If the SIP connections are not made over a private network, a
255: mechanism for securing the confidentiality and integrity of the SIP
256: connection MUST be used to protect the information.  One such
257: mechanism could be TLS encryption of the SIP signaling stream.
260: If the P-Charge-Info header field was accepted by a SIP entity from
261: an untrusted peer, there is the potential for fraud if the untrusted
262: entity sent incorrect information, either inadvertently or
264: Therefore, a SIP entity MUST remove and ignore the P-Charge-Info
265: header field when it is received from an untrusted entity.
267: If the P-Charge-Info header field was sent by a SIP entity to an
268: untrusted peer, there is potential for exposure of network
269: information that is internal to a trust domain.  For instance, the
270: untrusted entity may learn the identities of public SIP proxies used
271: within the trust domain, which could then potentially be directly
273: If an implementation does not strip P-Charge-Info from the message
274: where specified in this document, it introduces serious privacy
275: risks.  Examples include revealing third-party billing relationships
276: that might be sensitive, as well as unmasking the identity of callers
277: who wish to remain anonymous.  Depending on circumstances, the latter
278: case may result in unwanted harassment and even physical harm to the
280: Therefore, a SIP entity MUST remove the P-Charge-Info header field
281: when it is sent to an untrusted entity.

332: P-Charging-Vector is defined in Section 4.6 of [RFC7315] and used by
333: the 3GPP to carry information related to the charging of a session.
334: There are, however, some differences in the semantics associated with
335: P-Charging-Vector and P-Charge-Info.  P-Charging-Vector is mainly
336: used to carry information for correlation of multiple charging
337: records generated for a single session.  On the other hand,
338: P-Charge-Info is used to convey information about the party to be
339: billed for a call.  Furthermore, P-Charging-Vector has a mandatory
340: icid-value parameter that is a globally unique value to identify the
341: session for which the charging information is generated.  Such a
342: globally unique identifier is not necessary when carrying information
343: about the user to be billed when it is attached to the corresponding
346: P-DCS-Billing-Info is defined in Section 7 of [RFC5503] and used for
347: passing billing information between trusted entities in the
348: PacketCable Distributed Call Signaling Architecture.  For many
349: billing situations, particularly the very large-scale residential
350: telephone networks for which this header field is designed,
351: P-DCS-Billing-Info is an excellent solution.  However, this ability
352: to address a range of situations adds complexity.  According to RFC
353: 5503, the following information is mandatory to include in each use
355: o  Billing-Correlation-ID, a globally unique identifier
358: The P-DCS-Billing-Info header field may also include a variety of
360: While this may work well in many billing scenarios, there are other
361: billing scenarios that do not need this level of complexity.  In
362: those simpler scenarios, all that is needed is a number to use for
363: billing.  P-Charge-Info provides this simple solution for simple
365: Additionally, according to Section 7.3 of RFC 5503, it is mandatory
366: for a UA to create a Billing-Correlation-ID and insert this into the
367: P-DCS-Billing-Info header field (along with the other required
371: information) sent in the initial SIP INVITE.  This again makes sense
372: for the residential-telephone-service environment for which this
373: header field is designed.  In contrast, P-Charge-Info is designed to
374: be used among proxies and not at all by normal user agents.

378: Early reviewers of this document asked why the P-Asserted-Identity
379: header field documented in [RFC3325] could not be used.  As mentioned
380: in the use-case example above, P-Asserted-Identity is used to
381: indicate the identity of the calling party.  However, in this
382: instance, the requirement is to provide an additional identity of the
384: It would be typical to find both P-Asserted-Identity and
385: P-Charge-Info used in a SIP exchange.  P-Asserted-Identity would be
386: used to provide the caller identity that would be displayed to the
387: end user as "Caller ID", while P-Charge-Info would provide the
388: billing identifier used for the billing associated with the call.
